awd_titl_txt: Predicting emergent continuum-elastic properties of lipid membranes from molecular-level simulations via consistent and model-free scale bridging
awd_abstract_narration:
Markus Deserno from Carnegie Mellon University is supported by the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods Program of the Chemistry Division (CHE) and the Condensed Matter and Materials Theory Program of the Division of Materials Research (DMR) to develop computational approaches to predict the elastic properties of lipid membranes and to understand how protein filaments adsorbed onto these membranes exert forces upon them. These membranes, a combination of fat-like molecules, cholesterol and proteins, are complex entities across which metabolic intermediates enter and exit cells.  Most cellular membranes require frequent changes of their shape or even connectivity in order to execute their wide spectrum of biological functions. The underlying mechanics depends on a small number of parameters, which fully characterize both the energetic requirements for such deformations as well as the forces transmitted by them.  Deserno and his research group develop a set of new simulation strategies for predicting these parameters in computer simulations. The aim is  to gain access to physical  parameters that have been controversial or notoriously hard to obtain.   They also develop quantitative approaches to investigate one of the most common processes by which membrane connectivity is changed.   Graduate and undergraduate students working on these projects will gain experience in soft matter, biophysics, simulation, and continuum modeling. Ongoing outreach projects with both middle- and high schools in Pittsburgh will be extended by developing a lecture series closely tied with hands-on experimentation that develops the concept of elastic sheets and beams.  

This award supports theoretical and computational research and education to (1) measure emergent continuum-elastic properties of lipid membranes from molecular-level simulations via consistent and model-free scale bridging and to (2) develop theoretical techniques for describing the interaction of semi-flexible polymers with curved surfaces. In (1) the research involves expanding the information obtainable from simulating buckled membranes to extract not only the bending modulus, but identify its entropic contribution, the position of the pivotal plane of a single leaflet, and the magnitude of the spontaneous monolayer curvature. These techniques are applied to computational membrane models spanning a wide range of resolution, from atomistic to highly coarse-grained. Particular applications include lipid bilayers that are strongly stiffened when entering a gel phase, or strongly softened by trace amounts of small peptides.  Deserno and coworkers also aim  to measure the Gaussian curvature modulus by expanding the dynamic patch closure protocol to an equilibrium measurement based on externally confining fields, which after accounting for composition-curvature coupling can be generalized to the nontrivial case of lipid mixtures. In (2)  Deserno explores the geometric nature of elastic forces that result from confining one-dimensional semi-flexible polymers to curved surfaces. Building on the case of a confining cylinder, which has both a continuous rotation and translation symmetry, the Euler-Lagrange equations for the shape are to be solved through a combination of analytical and numerical techniques, and the associated stresses and torques are identified. Moving on to a confining catenoid, translational symmetry is lost, as is generally a potential quadrature, but the new curvature gradients provide a host of new physics, linked to boundary conditions, curvature localization, and polymerization forces. Geodesics and asymptotic curves are studied as limiting cases for polymers with anisotropic elastic properties, and additional spontaneous curvature and twist render the filament an excellent continuum model for dynamin filaments. This allows the prediction of forces exerted by dynamin helices polymerizing around membrane necks, a process that is believed to underlie many cellular membrane fission events, but whose mechanistic underpinning is still not understood.

por.por_cntn:
Lipid membranes form the boundaries of all living cells, and in so-called eukaryotic cells (in particular those in all animals and humans) they furthermore create a wide array of distinct membrane organelles, such as the wall of the cell nucleus, the endoplasmic reticulum, the Golgi apparatus, or mitochondria. Cells must reshape their membranes in order to move, take up material, or transport it once it is inside them. They use membranes to maintain distinct biochemical environments and to protect themselves from toxins and pathogens that could be harmful. Conversely, these pathogens---many of which also are surrounded by membranes---have evolved ingenious ways to circumvent these cellular barriers, and understanding the way they do this is an important aspect of fighting pathogen-born illnesses.

Membranes accomplish many tasks, and in doing so rely on their amazing elastic properties: they are two-dimensional fluids, much like soap films, but they also resist bending. This research project has studied membrane elasticity and its molecular foundation: how can we measure it accurately, how can we study it in computer simulations, and how can we understand it based on our knowledge of a membrane's structural basis---a molecularly thin double sheet of lipid molecules (a "lipid bilayer")? Furthermore, how can we describe what happens when membranes are in contact with elastic filaments that bind to it? This situation is difficult to treat, because a filament's shape might not be compatible with the resting shape of a membrane, leading to a tug-of-war in which each player strives to pull the other into its preferred shape. Of particular biological interest are filaments winding around a membrane neck (a "wormhole"-like connection between two big membranes). This geometry is a good model for the biological process of dynamin-driven membrane fission, a ubiquitous event by which a filamentous helical protein winds around such a neck, constricts it, and ultimately cuts it through.

The scientific outcomes produced by the PI and his students and postdocs in the context of this award include the following:

  • With the help of computer simulations, we discovered that membranes in a low-temperature ("gel"-) phase become softer when being bent. We developed a theory to quantitatively model this unexpected phenomenon, and it explains the simulation results very well.
  • We showed that laterally compressing membranes until they buckle out of shape is an efficient way to determine not only their rigidity, but also the location of their pivotal plane (the surface within each bilayer leaflet that gets neither stretched nor compressed upon bending). We also showed that buckling permits us to measure how strongly curvature deformations tilt lipids away from their usual direction perpendicular to the membrane, and thus measure the important but hard to access "lipid tilt-modulus".
  • We developed a novel theory for the way in which membrane curvature and lipid tilt couple to one another, improving existing microscopic descriptions of a membrane's macroscopic behavior.
  • For a closed elastic filament resting on a cylindrical surface, the equations describing the filament's shape can be (almost) completely solved, and we used this to classify the resulting shapes and transitions between them.
  • When open elastic filaments, which additionally prefer to take the shape of spirals, rest on the more complicated shape of a membrane neck, modeled by the more complicated shape of a so-called "catenoid", the equation for the filament is too complicated to be solved by pen and paper, but it can still be solved numerically. In this way we showed that passive constriction of necks by dynamin spirals is unlikely to promote fission.
  • Conversely, by numerically investigating the equations for a membrane's shape held in the frame of a helical filament, we showed that stable solutions always exist, thereby invalidating the old idea that changes in dynamin's helical radius or pitch could somehow destabilize the underlying membrane as a whole and thereby cut it.
  • Finally, we also developed a computational model for dynamin-driven fission, in which both filament and membrane are explicitly represented (but not at full atomistic resolution) and used it to test a number of previously hypothesized fission scenarios. We found that an additional "twirling" motion of the filament strongly boosts efficiency, which is in line with the experimentally observed tilting of dynamin's binding domain to membranes.

This award offered teaching and training opportunities for seven PhD students, four of whom have defended their thesis by now, two postdoctoral researchers, two undergraduate students, and one exchange student. Moreover, the PI and his students have conducted outreach activities with local middle- and high schools, reaching from lecture demonstrations over month-long self-developed experiments, to preparation for science fairs.
